title: Cannot open game pass game, throws UnauthorizedAccessException
body:
I'm fairly new to all of this, but I do program for a living. I'm playing through a, uh, _foxy_ new game released this week and wished to export the manual pages from within the game to give myself a nice version of them for translation efforts, printing, etc.

I've installed it via Game Pass/the Xbox app, which means it's thrown in with all the rest of the app store binaries under `C:\Program Files\WindowsApps\`. This directory is typically unreadable by most users, so after working up the guts from reading enough tutorials to make me think it safe, I changed that entire directory's owner to the _Administrators_ group. Since I'm an admin, I can now browse it (in e.g. Windows Explorer) fine, even without _Run as Administrator_.

However, attempting to _Load Folder_ from Asset Studio (I downloaded the `net5` variant) results in the following error:

```
************** Exception Text **************
System.UnauthorizedAccessException: Access to the path 'C:\Program Files\WindowsApps\Finji.TUNIC_1.0.8.0_x64__tys0ffscxatjj\Secret Legend.exe' is denied.
   at System.IO.FileStream.ValidateFileHandle(SafeFileHandle fileHandle)
   at System.IO.FileStream.CreateFileOpenHandle(FileMode mode, FileShare share, FileOptions options)
   at System.IO.FileStream..ctor(String path, FileMode mode, FileAccess access, FileShare share, Int32 bufferSize, FileOptions options)
   at AssetStudio.AssetsManager.Load(String[] files) in C:\projects\assetstudio\AssetStudio\AssetsManager.cs:line 51
   at AssetStudio.AssetsManager.LoadFolder(String path) in C:\projects\assetstudio\AssetStudio\AssetsManager.cs:line 36
   at AssetStudioGUI.AssetStudioGUIForm.<>c__DisplayClass52_0.<loadFolder_Click>b__0() in C:\projects\assetstudio\AssetStudioGUI\AssetStudioGUIForm.cs:line 163
   at System.Threading.Tasks.Task.InnerInvoke()
   at System.Threading.Tasks.Task.<>c.<.cctor>b__277_0(Object obj)
   at System.Threading.ExecutionContext.RunFromThreadPoolDispatchLoop(Thread threadPoolThread, ExecutionContext executionContext, ContextCallback callback, Object state)
--- End of stack trace from previous location ---
   at System.Threading.ExecutionContext.RunFromThreadPoolDispatchLoop(Thread threadPoolThread, ExecutionContext executionContext, ContextCallback callback, Object state)
   at System.Threading.Tasks.Task.ExecuteWithThreadLocal(Task& currentTaskSlot, Thread threadPoolThread)
--- End of stack trace from previous location ---
   at AssetStudioGUI.AssetStudioGUIForm.loadFolder_Click(Object sender, EventArgs e) in C:\projects\assetstudio\AssetStudioGUI\AssetStudioGUIForm.cs:line 163
   at System.Threading.Tasks.Task.<>c.<ThrowAsync>b__140_0(Object state)
```

The program does this whether or not I launch it with _Run As Administrator_. The program seems to be able to open other files in that same directory tree just fine, but the `exe` itself is a problem. Its owner and group don't seem problematic, and I can launch and play the game myself just fine.

Is this expected, or am I doing something wrong?
author: jasonmp85

comments.body:
Although you have administrator rights, the exe file may be read-only, and you need to modify the permissions of this file separately.
But I think you can consider copying all files other than exe to other folders, and then operate.

Hm, yeah I don't know these tools that well (I'm a Mac/Linux guy) and it looks like maybe the owners and permissions weren't recursing down like I expected. That all aside, I moved the `exe` files elsewhere for a bit and everything worked! Because it tried to open them, I assumed it needed them for some of its functionality, but the results seemed pretty complete once I moved the executables. Thanks!

title: If the game is macOS version, AssetStudio try to read "unity default resources" from wrong path
body:
in macOS, "unity default resources" file are located in `Game.app/Contents/Resources/unity default resources`, and other resources are `Game.app/Contents/Resources/Data/*`.

but AssetStudio try to read "unity default resources from `Game.app/Contents/Resources/Data/` instead of `Game.app/Contents/Resources/`, and it throws unhandled FileNotFoundException.
author: iokotono

comments.body:
Very strange error, AssetStudio will try to read unless the file exists, and it is impossible to throw FileNotFoundException anyway. 
Please upload the complete file to me if possible.
it seems to bug of wine-mono, just install Microsoft .NET and works. sorry.

title: Importing Textures?
body:
so umm, im trying to mod a game, but i cant find any sort of "import" button.
how do you import textures?
author: KitOdin

comments.body: as far as i am aware this is a tool to extract and view. not to insert

while it was intended to extract and view, the addition of an import feature would be helpful. There so far isn't any active tools that support modern unity versions like this one. so a import tool to replace textures, meshes, etc. would be extremely helpful and maybe even the first to allow basic texture modding and model swapping.
You can try UnityPy

title: 2 issues: non-standard normal maps and transparent surfaces
body:
Issue 1: Many Unity games utilize unique red-tinted normal maps. Would it be possible to add a converter that would automatically change them to the traditional purple?

Issue 2:
When importing an FBX model into blender, only the diffuse and normal textures are loaded, no specular/reflectivity maps. Also, the alpha channel is set to the diffuse texture, resulting in all surfaces being translucent.
author: jkerman2000

comments.body:
1. I will consider adding, but I still recommend users to convert by themselves.
2. The program can only guess the attribute of the texture by the file name, so under normal circumstances, the program will not try to identify it, only export all, you need to manually set it yourself.

title: Monobehaviour dump and UABE
body:
Hello ! 
Thanks, I'd like to thank you for your work on AssetStudio.
I'm not sure it's been asked before, but I understand AS doesn't have an import function, which makes UABE the only (?) viable solution to import dump into assets for modding. 
If I understand well, AS and UABE don't use the same class structures to dump Monobehaviour as json/txt. So I was wondering if there is a way to make both dumps compatible, so it would be possible to import AS Dump files with UABE. 

I hope it's rather clear, English isn't my native language. 
Thanks in advance.
author: seelebrn

comments.body:
AssetStudio will not consider supporting UABE format.
You can currently try to use UnityPy to edit MonoBehaviour.

title: How to export MonoBehaviour with dummy DLL?
body:
In  the README.md, you mentioned AssetStudio can export MonoBehaviour with assembly DLL. But when I first select MonoBehaviour, it doesn't ask me the directory where the assembly is located. How to specify the dummy folder?

您好，
  您在README中提到，当第一次选择一个MonoBehaviour资源时，AssetStudio会提示指定dll文件夹在哪里。对于il2cpp而言，需要指定dummyDLL文件夹。但是我选择了一个MonoBehaviour之后，并没有要求我指定对应的文件夹。请问应该如何指定文件夹，导出正确的文件？
author: StKelen

comments.body:
如果你的MonoBehaviour是在bundle文件里，并且bundle带有MonoBehaviour的结构信息的话，就不会向你要求dll文件。
点击MonoBehaviour查看时可以看右下角，如果MonoBehaviour读取出错会有提示，没有的话MonoBehaviour的结构就是你看到的样子。
好哒，感谢~~

comments.body:
You need to upload the source file to me and describe it in detail.
In addition, I don’t know how you can judge whether the picture is transparent. If you are also black in the preview, it proves that there is no transparent information.
AssetStudio only supports separate extraction of models, if you need prefab, please consider using UnityRipper.

title: Large memory usage.
body:
What the fuck. I have only 16gb ram and this program use all of that. 
If I understand that this program decodes all files, and it doesn't matter if this file is opened in preview or not.
Who in the world use this. 
Fix this problem. If you look at other programs of this kind you won't see a lot of memory usage there.
author: Gigabait

comments.body:
I think you are opening a bundle file, if you open it directly, AssetStudio will decompress it in the memory and read it, so it will take up a lot of memory.
You can use v0.15.5 and later version, use File-Extract file or File-Extract folder to decompress the bundle file to the local, and then load it with AssetStudio,

@Perfare Now i use latest version. I decompressed folder and load it with AssetStudio. About a 8k files... And it still uses a lot of memory.
Why programm read all files ? Its very bad. Why not just write all decompressed file names to ListView and after user click to file in line of the ListView it was be read ?

Note that the decompressed file should not be placed in the same folder as the original file.
This is the way the program was originally designed, I don’t have more energy to refactor, sorry.

title: Audio Files Missing
body:
This may or may not be related to this amazing software:
The game One Piece Bounty Rush is one of those where you must download additional files upon first launch. 
After the download, if I use this (or UABE) to extract all the .unity3D files, I get a bunch of stuff, but no audio files. Nothing in the OBB folder, either. 
So, as far as I can tell, either the audio files are compressed again somehow within the .unity3D files, or AssetStudio is not able to see them (along with UABE).
author: Frogman9

comments.body: If you load all the Unity files and do not see the AudioClip, it usually means that the game may not use Unity's audio system. This is actually very common. At this time, the audio files should be placed in a separate folder. Or the game may encrypt the audio. Putting it in TextAsset is possible. Further research is needed.

> If you load all the Unity files and do not see the AudioClip, it usually means that the game may not use Unity's audio system. This is actually very common. At this time, the audio files should be placed in a separate folder. Or the game may encrypt the audio. Putting it in TextAsset is possible. Further research is needed.

I have been poking around and still haven't found where they tucked the audio files, what could they encrypt them with or would there be any rhyme or reason to the hiding them in the TextAsset?

> > If you load all the Unity files and do not see the AudioClip, it usually means that the game may not use Unity's audio system. This is actually very common. At this time, the audio files should be placed in a separate folder. Or the game may encrypt the audio. Putting it in TextAsset is possible. Further research is needed.
> 
> I have been poking around and still haven't found where they tucked the audio files, what could they encrypt them with or would there be any rhyme or reason to the hiding them in the TextAsset?

can u check the streaming assets folder to see if the audio files are in .BANK format? cause then u can turn them into .FSB and then extract them to .wav

normally ,i just export all Texture2D files and search them one by one.

comments.body:
Under normal circumstances, the texture will be exported together when fbx is output. If not, it means that there is no texture bound on the material.
mesh does not output textures because mesh does not contain any texture information.

title: Question with Windows 8 game
body:
I want to datamine a game for Windows 8 but the game doesn't have the **Managed** directory in **Data**, the DLLs are in the root of the directory of the game (Extracted APPX/installed package). Luckily Sega left an internal compilation file called managedAssemblies.txt that lists them which helps me find them. Do I have to create a directory with them or can AssetStudio just find them when I locate the root of the game directory?

Unity Version: 4.7.2f1
Game: Sonic Dash
Developer: SEGA
Game Platform: Windows 8
Version: 3.6.4.0 (ARM/X86)
AssetStudio Version: 0.13.25.0
author: LolHacksRule

comments.body: The dll file will only be used when reading MonoBehaviour. When you click MonoBehaviour, you will be prompted to select the folder where the dll is located.

title: DumpScript fails on wwise objects
body:
Phoenix Point uses wwise audio and the script dumper will fail on any asset that has a field of certain wwise types. The root issue seems to be that these objects have a "valueGuidInternal" field of type byte[]. The dumper attempts to read this array by re-aligning the stream after each byte, but all the array elements are packed in the asset file with no padding between them.

I am unsure if the packing behavior is specific to these wwise types or would be the case for all arrays of byte (or boolean?). I have made a local change that skips alignment after reading a primitive type if the type is an array element, instead re-aligning after processing the whole array. This seems to work for Phoenix Point but I don't know if it will break other games.
author: tracktwo

comments.body: Reading MonoBehaviours is an unfinished feature and I will try to improve it when I have time.

title: Suggestion: export from an AssetBundle with the directory structure specified in the container
body:
Currently, when exporting assets from an AssetBundle the files are exported in a directory named after the SerializedFile name, which is definitely a sensible choice.
However, often the assets in the AssetBundle are part of containers that have their own directory structure specified, which allows a more intuitive placement of the exported assets. I think it would be nice to allow the option of recreating the directory structure using a specfied folder as root, with the assets exported at this point in the subdirectory having the name of the container.
 
E.g. CAB-1234 contains the Mesh B-LOD0 and the Texture2D B_alb as part of a container having the internal name and path assets/main/content/models/B.asset, the option would allow to specify a path, create the path /assets/main/content/models/B.asset directory, and then would export B-LOD0 and B_alb in said directory.
author: LudwigvonWu

comments.body:
`Options – Display asset original name` and `Do not group`
Should be what you want.

@Perfare That didn't work. I checked Options->"Display asset original name" and selected Options->"Do not group", then Export->"All assets", and it dumped all files in the same folder.

Is AssetStudio even aware of containers in asset bundles? I can't find that info displayed anywhere in the program, not a column or anything.

For people who have the problem.
AssetStudio -> Options -> Export options -> Group exported assets by -> container path
Should put all assets in folders corresponding to their container path.

title: Assetstudio seems to not export rigged models correctly
body: Currently all rigged models on my end always export as unrigged models no matter what i do.
author: Bits360

comments.body: Usually because the file does not contain bone information, or the bone information cannot be found normally.
